Still not shaken by anger and rage, which could have very well happened due=
 to his extremely short temper, Tucson continues his poetic interlude with =
artful grace and a sense of undisturbed tranquility. =A0His arms and hands =
follow the flow of water that jets out of the fissures.  Yet the water simp=
ly follows the flow of his arms rather than splashing on them.  And with th=
e water came the compulsion to transform into his beast form.   And then as=
 warrior once again became the dragon, he embraces the element of water and=
 melds with its own natural forces and then, with his powerful tail, he str=
ikes the wall, attempting to finally break it to further weaken it.

Fire m=
ay not have been his theme but he embraces something far more significant t=
han simple flames.  The element of Thunder, and lightning and the raging to=
rrent of rain water that follows the first clap of thunder.  He gives a dra=
conic roar that sends a thunderous boom toward the Sharkticon guards, and t=
hroughout the cavern.

He can hear Yoketron's phrases as he carries forth a=
nd recites them to his enemies.

" Fire may be powerful and capable of mass=
ive damage, yet fire is not the most formidable element of nature.  For it =
has a weakness, water.  And even more powerful than water, is the storm tha=
t spawns it.  Embrace the power of the storm, be at one with the tempest, a=
nd bring forth the light that follows darkness. "

Tucson's armor shimmers =
as the glint on each metallic scale flashes like lightning. He stands his g=
round and begins moving his wings, kicking up a slight breeze in the cave.
=

" I am the storm, and I will not be easily stopped.  Your darkness will se=
e light, like it or not."
